description: Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) is an introductory Microsoft certification for individuals considering a career in technology. The Windows Server Administration Fundamentals exam is designed to provide an assessment of knowledge of fundamental server administration concepts. It covers a wide range of topics, such as Windows Server, Windows-based networking, Active Directory, and system recovery. Upon completing the 98-365 exam, you will earn a Microsoft Technology Associate certification, which helps prove your knowledge of fundamental technology concepts. It can also serve as a stepping stone to the Microsoft Certified Technology Specialist exams.
name: MTA - Server Fundamentals - 98-365
subtitle: Windows Server Administration Fundamentals

episodes.description: Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) is an introductory Microsoft certification for individuals considering a career in technology. The Windows Server Administration Fundamentals exam is designed to provide an assessment of knowledge of fundamental server administration concepts. It covers a wide range of topics, such as Windows Server, Windows-based networking, Active Directory, and system recovery. Upon completing the 98-365 exam, you will earn a Microsoft Technology Associate certification, which helps prove your knowledge of fundamental technology concepts. It can also serve as a stepping stone to the Microsoft Certified Technology Specialist exams.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.070 --> 00:00:07.220
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.220 --> 00:00:11.068
In this segment, we're gonna
take you through an overview of

3
00:00:11.068 --> 00:00:15.742
the MTA Windows Server Administration
Fundamentals 98-365 exam.

4
00:00:15.742 --> 00:00:16.694
Wow, that was a mouthful.

5
00:00:16.694 --> 00:00:17.320
>> [LAUGH] It is.

6
00:00:17.320 --> 00:00:19.350
>> But, it is a really good exam for you,

7
00:00:19.350 --> 00:00:22.750
especially if you're trying to get
into server administration itself.

8
00:00:22.750 --> 00:00:26.300
It does help for us to have a core
knowledge of Windows server

9
00:00:26.300 --> 00:00:29.820
operating systems if that is the
environment which we are going to support.

10
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:32.650
Microsoft does a great job of
breaking this exam down for

11
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:36.325
us, telling us exactly what we need to
do to pass it, how much it's gonna cost,

12
00:00:36.325 --> 00:00:38.425
where we can get signed up for it.

13
00:00:38.425 --> 00:00:41.375
Mike, you're gonna give us some of
the details according to this, right?

14
00:00:41.375 --> 00:00:42.295
>> Yes, I am.

15
00:00:42.295 --> 00:00:46.895
The MTA exams, and there are several of
them, are really foundational skills.

16
00:00:46.895 --> 00:00:50.020
They're designed to to test
our core knowledge and

17
00:00:50.020 --> 00:00:53.810
see if we're ready to move on
into a career based in idea.

18
00:00:53.810 --> 00:01:00.150
If we want to move into that MCSA track or
that MCSE track if we take these exams,

19
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:04.220
these will let us know, hey, are we ready
or maybe we need to do some more studying?

20
00:01:04.220 --> 00:01:08.216
>> Another good reason as to look at
taking one of these exams is just to get

21
00:01:08.216 --> 00:01:12.713
your feet wet and see if maybe this is
a career you're interested in pursuing.

22
00:01:12.713 --> 00:01:17.752
Maybe you've never done anything in IT and
you're thinking about it.

23
00:01:17.752 --> 00:01:19.780
This is a great exam to start with.

24
00:01:19.780 --> 00:01:23.110
Maybe you've worked with
computers outside, at home,

25
00:01:23.110 --> 00:01:25.160
you've dibble-dabbled here and there.

26
00:01:25.160 --> 00:01:29.350
Let's see how much you know, how close
are you to starting that MTSA track.

27
00:01:29.350 --> 00:01:33.340
Or for an IT person maybe that got
the job without any certification,

28
00:01:33.340 --> 00:01:36.248
back in the day before
the certifications were really used,

29
00:01:36.248 --> 00:01:41.400
or just got promoted within a company and
now you want to get certified.

30
00:01:41.400 --> 00:01:43.740
Are you ready to make that next step?

31
00:01:43.740 --> 00:01:46.390
This is a great starting point for you.

32
00:01:46.390 --> 00:01:50.030
And the Microsoft Technology
Associate Program,

33
00:01:50.030 --> 00:01:53.620
they have several different exams that
you can take, as Daniel mentioned.

34
00:01:53.620 --> 00:01:57.420
This is the server
administration fundamentals.

35
00:01:57.420 --> 00:01:58.360
So let's take a look at it.

36
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:00.920
Here on my screen I've got,
Microsoft has a great page,

37
00:02:00.920 --> 00:02:04.060
all you gotta do is go out there,
use your favorite search engine.

38
00:02:04.060 --> 00:02:08.110
Search for Microsoft Technology Associate
and you can find this page, and

39
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:12.770
Microsoft talks about the fact that it's
an introductory Microsoft certification

40
00:02:12.770 --> 00:02:16.440
for people considering
a career in technology.

41
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:20.850
Now these exams are not going
to qualify you for the MCP,

42
00:02:20.850 --> 00:02:23.120
the Microsoft Certified Professional.

43
00:02:23.120 --> 00:02:28.430
You need to take one of our MCSA or
MCSE tracks to get that qualification.

44
00:02:28.430 --> 00:02:33.900
But also not a prereq for
an MCSA or an MCSE or an MCSD.

45
00:02:33.900 --> 00:02:38.387
So don't think that you have to take
this if you're moving on into an MCSA or

46
00:02:38.387 --> 00:02:41.678
MCSD, but it is, like I said,
a good starting point.

47
00:02:41.678 --> 00:02:46.440
If you don't have any certifications, this
is probably where you'd like to start.

48
00:02:46.440 --> 00:02:50.210
Down below, I can see I've got
the choice of these different tracks.

49
00:02:50.210 --> 00:02:53.170
Am I thinking about going
into IT infrastructure?

50
00:02:53.170 --> 00:02:59.060
I want to manage clients and servers, and
work with the network infrastructure.

51
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:02.120
Am I gonna,
am I thinking I might be interested

52
00:03:02.120 --> 00:03:06.810
in pursuing a career working with
databases, with Microsoft SQL Server?

53
00:03:06.810 --> 00:03:10.490
Or do I want to be a developer, do I want
to learn to program and things like that?

54
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:11.770
So, whichever one you want.

55
00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:14.980
This one falls under
the IT infrastructure and

56
00:03:14.980 --> 00:03:18.690
we can see down here, Windows Server
administration fundamentals.

57
00:03:18.690 --> 00:03:22.990
And as Daniel gave us that exam number,
98-365

58
00:03:22.990 --> 00:03:27.590
is the one we're going to be going
over in the episodes to come.

59
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:31.850
Now, this exam is going to cost
you about $115 US, all right?

60
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:36.210
And you can take that exam through
either Certiport or Pearson VUE.

61
00:03:37.640 --> 00:03:41.770
The exam itself, we can come down here and
we can take a look at the objectives.

62
00:03:41.770 --> 00:03:44.260
I'll just go ahead and click show all.

63
00:03:44.260 --> 00:03:47.330
And I love these pages, cause if
you're getting ready for a test, and

64
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:50.090
you wanna make sure you're
ready to walk into that booth,

65
00:03:50.090 --> 00:03:52.540
this is a great place to go,

66
00:03:52.540 --> 00:03:55.884
It talks about understanding
server installation.

67
00:03:55.884 --> 00:04:00.053
I've gotta be familiar with the way
drivers work, how I can make sure they're

68
00:04:00.053 --> 00:04:04.172
running, and start them and stop them,
and change who they're running as.

69
00:04:04.172 --> 00:04:08.090
I've got understand, I'm sorry,
it was the services and drivers.

70
00:04:08.090 --> 00:04:11.000
I've got understand my different
server options for installation,

71
00:04:11.000 --> 00:04:17.760
like core versus full,
doing unattended installs, doing images.

72
00:04:17.760 --> 00:04:19.710
When it gets down to server roles,

I've gotta be familiar with all those

74

Application servers, web servers,
remote access servers, file and

75

print servers, server virtualization.

76
00:04:31.740 --> 00:04:33.420
We keep going down.

77

Active directory,
we gotta be familiar with that.

78

That's a major part of

79

Active Directory is our authentication,
is part of it.

80
00:04:43.350 --> 00:04:44.760
It does so much more.

81
00:04:46.140 --> 00:04:50.810
Working with domain accounts,
working with organizational units and

82
00:04:50.810 --> 00:04:54.840
understanding the way the infrastructure
is laid out, like your forest, and

83
00:04:54.840 --> 00:04:58.150
your parent domains,
and your child domains.

84
00:04:58.150 --> 00:04:58.880
Group policy,

85

another huge part of managing a network

86
00:05:04.450 --> 00:05:06.980
Understanding different types of storage.

87

All of our different SATA or
SCSI or iSCSIs,

88

89

Then we move on down into server

90
00:05:19.939 --> 00:05:22.219
working with the different subsystems,

91
00:05:22.219 --> 00:05:27.244
The main four, processor, memory, disk and

92
00:05:27.244 --> 00:05:31.465
so that I know if a server is performing
as it should or is not performing like

93

it should or is unable to handle
the workload and what I can do about it.

94
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:37.565
I've gotta be able to figure that out.

95
00:05:37.565 --> 00:05:40.950
Reading log files, one of the most
exciting jobs you'll have in IT.

96
00:05:40.950 --> 00:05:42.725
[LAUGH] Reading log files.

97
00:05:42.725 --> 00:05:43.725
Just kidding.

98

But it's a part of it, right?

99
00:05:45.025 --> 00:05:46.435
I've gotta understand it.

100

I've gotta know what I'm looking for.

101
00:05:48.289 --> 00:05:53.935
Server maintenance,
troubleshooting the start-up process.

102
00:05:53.935 --> 00:05:59.020
Business continuity, disaster recovery,
hot sites, cold sites.

103
00:05:59.020 --> 00:05:59.820
Updates, right?

104
00:05:59.820 --> 00:06:04.194
Running your own update server, going
out to Microsoft and getting updates,

105
00:06:04.194 --> 00:06:07.122
testing updates,
troubleshooting methodology.

106
00:06:07.122 --> 00:06:09.096
And I think that was
the last domain there.

107
00:06:09.096 --> 00:06:15.560
So you can see a very broad spectrum of
skills that this exam is gonna go over.

108
00:06:15.560 --> 00:06:19.340
With that being said,
it's not a very deep exam, right?

109
00:06:19.340 --> 00:06:23.390
This is a foundational knowledge,
so yes it's broad.

110
00:06:23.390 --> 00:06:27.910
It's like we say, it's like a mile
wide but an inch deep type thing.

111

You're gonna need to know little
bits about all of this stuff, but

112
00:06:31.500 --> 00:06:36.150
they're not gonna expect you to set up
a Federation Services Server on this exam.

113
00:06:36.150 --> 00:06:39.630
>> You probably won't even need to know
what that is, to be honest with you.

114
00:06:39.630 --> 00:06:43.340
Mike is right, it does cover
a myriad of different topics, but

115
00:06:43.340 --> 00:06:45.880
it doesn't want you to go super in-depth.

116
00:06:45.880 --> 00:06:50.590
It's all about, do I understand
the fundamentals, hence the idea here,

117
00:06:50.590 --> 00:06:53.310
right, Server Administrator Fundamentals.

118
00:06:53.310 --> 00:06:56.330
Understand the fundamental terms and
ideas and

119
00:06:56.330 --> 00:06:59.530
administration behind
a Microsoft server environment.

120
00:06:59.530 --> 00:07:03.020
The stuff we talked about,
right, understanding storage.

121
00:07:03.020 --> 00:07:06.360
Storage is a big part of
being a server administrator.

122
00:07:06.360 --> 00:07:10.640
You have to have at least some basic
knowledge of the different storage types

123
00:07:10.640 --> 00:07:13.140
so that you can help
administrate that system.

124
00:07:13.140 --> 00:07:15.570
If you have no idea what iSCSI is, well,

125
00:07:15.570 --> 00:07:18.070
you're going to have a difficult time
helping out when it comes to that.

126
00:07:18.070 --> 00:07:22.090
And that's what this exam is
really designed to help you grasp,

127
00:07:22.090 --> 00:07:26.280
really give you that core
foundational knowledge so

128
00:07:26.280 --> 00:07:30.200
that when you're ready,
you can work as a server administrator.

129
00:07:30.200 --> 00:07:35.840
Then you go into that MCSA and then
eventually that MCSE and start building

130
00:07:35.840 --> 00:07:39.900
your certifications through Microsoft so
that you can say, I have started from

131
00:07:39.900 --> 00:07:44.040
that foundation to their apex of their
little triangle that they love to show.

132
00:07:44.040 --> 00:07:46.900
It is, it is a good little
graphic that they give you

133
00:07:46.900 --> 00:07:48.520
to say I've worked my way
through all of these.

134
00:07:48.520 --> 00:07:51.260
It starts right here with the MTA.

135
00:07:51.260 --> 00:07:51.830
>> Exactly.

136
00:07:51.830 --> 00:07:53.740
Now that's what this exam is designed for.

137
00:07:53.740 --> 00:07:57.300
If you're already in the field and
you want to move up the food chain.

138
00:07:57.300 --> 00:08:01.140
You want to get off of the,
where ever you're at and move into the IT

139
00:08:01.140 --> 00:08:04.850
part of your company and work your way up,
this is a good one to start with.

140
00:08:04.850 --> 00:08:07.130
It proves that core knowledge.

141
00:08:07.130 --> 00:08:10.760
If you've never been in IT, this is a
great one to say, let me come in here and

142
00:08:10.760 --> 00:08:14.190
study for this exam, and
take this exam, pass it,

143
00:08:14.190 --> 00:08:15.780
it does a couple of things for you.

144
00:08:15.780 --> 00:08:20.060
One, hopefully,
Is it that got you excited, right?

145
00:08:20.060 --> 00:08:22.900
In studying for this you're like,
oh this is really great stuff.

146
00:08:22.900 --> 00:08:27.340
This is something I can see
myself doing for a living, right?

147
00:08:27.340 --> 00:08:30.230
Two, it gives you your
first certification.

148
00:08:30.230 --> 00:08:33.850
So now when you go apply for that job,
you've already got a certification.

149
00:08:33.850 --> 00:08:36.580
You can walk in and say look,
I've got an MTA and

150
00:08:36.580 --> 00:08:38.930
Windows server
administration fundamentals.

151
00:08:38.930 --> 00:08:41.600
And that proves to that
employer that you've got that

152
00:08:41.600 --> 00:08:43.790
core foundational knowledge already.

153
00:08:43.790 --> 00:08:48.190
And so if they're gonna hire you, they
know you've already got that information

154
00:08:48.190 --> 00:08:51.340
and it won't take much to get
you to move to that next step.

155
00:08:51.340 --> 00:08:55.400
So it's a really good stepping stone,
whether you're in IT or

156
00:08:55.400 --> 00:08:57.330
whether you're just getting started.

157
00:08:57.330 --> 00:09:00.970
>> Well hopefully that has piqued
your curiosity on the MTA exam.

158
00:09:00.970 --> 00:09:03.735
And stay tuned, because we're gonna
have great episodes coming up, and

159
00:09:03.735 --> 00:09:04.991
hopefully we'll see you there.

160
00:09:04.991 --> 00:09:11.659
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel take a look at device drivers. They walk you through understanding exactly what a device driver is and how to install them. They also explain some of the common administrative tasks like how to upgrade, uninstall, and troubleshoot drivers.
episodes.title: Understand Device Drivers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the topic of services. They define what services are and why they're important to systems administrators. They then describe how services can be configured, the different startup types, and even creating service accounts.
episodes.title: Understand Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike give you an overview of the different installation options for Windows Server 2008R2. They describe the many different versions of Server 2008R2, as well as the types of installations; specifically unattended vs. attended and upgrade vs. clean install all while actually installing Windows Server 2008R2 step-by-step.
episodes.title: Server Installation Options

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue exploring Server 20082 installation fundamentals; kicking things off with F8 boot options. Then they describe the differences and similarities between Windows Server 2008R2 Core vs. Full versions. Also covered are best practices concerning BIOS and Firmware updates.
episodes.title: Server Install Options Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the unique attributes of different application servers. Here you will learn what makes a Mail server different from a Database server or a Web server and how/why we use these servers as well as Collaboration servers like Microsoft's Sharepoint, Monitoring servers, and Threat Management servers.
episodes.title: Identify Application Servers

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain how a Web server, like Microsoft's Internet Information Services(IIS) server, is used to make available a website. They also explain secure web traffic as well as using a web server to transfer files using the File Transfer Protocol(FTP).
episodes.title: Web Servers

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe Remote Access and the different methods employed to gain access to a remote system. They show you how to use the remote solutions provided by Microsoft Windows and Server products like Remote Desktop, used mostly by administrators, and Remote Assistance, used as a remote help desk access tool.
episodes.title: Remote Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the file and print services found in the Windows Server operating system. Here they show you how to connect both local and network printers and then move into more complex options like printer pools and web printing and management. Also covered is driver deployment, auditing and print job management.
episodes.title: File and Print Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain the concept of server virtualization. They walk you through creating virtual hard drives and virtual machines using Microsoft's virtualization software Hyper-V allowing them to explain many of the different options available like, memory allocation, creating virtual networks, and taking snapshots of virtual machines allowing you to revert to a previous state after making changes.
episodes.title: Server Virtualization

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel delve into User Accounts and Groups in both Workgroup/Local and Active Directory environments. Here they explain the difference between the two types of accounts as well as going over the group types and scopes. Also covered is the Microsoft recommended strategy for assigning permissions.
episodes.title: Accounts and Groups

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain Organizational Units and Containers found in Microsoft's Active Directory. They walk you through the purpose, plan, and practical implementation of OUs as well as showing you how to create custom OUs for your own purposes. Also covered is how to use OUs to delegate authority.
episodes.title: OUs and Containers

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the Active Directory Infrastructure. Here they take you through a myriad of topics such as: Domain Controllers, Forests, Domains, Replication, and Operational Roles.
episodes.title: AD Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss Group Policy for controlling a Windows Active Directory environment. They start by explaining the how, when, and where Group Policy is applied to computers and/or users; then they show you how to create Group Policy Objects (GPO) in your own domain or local computer.
episodes.title: Group Policy

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the different common storage technologies in use in a Windows Server environment. They cover the advantages and disadvantages of each as they explain storage solutions like NAS, SAN, Fibre Channel, iSCSI, and NFS as well as some of the hardware requirements needed for them.
episodes.title: Storage Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain how to you can both protect and optimize your storage solutions using RAID technologies. The Redundant Array of Independent Disks solutions covered are RAID Level 0, 1, 5, and 10 giving you a basic understanding of the most common RAID solutions in use today.
episodes.title: Understanding RAID

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike introduce you to the disk management inside of Windows Server 2008 R2. They walk you through understanding the different types of disks you may encounter as well as the filesystems that you can use to make them usable by the Operating System to store files.
episodes.title: Disk Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike crack open an actual server to help you learn to identify some of the major hardware components found within. Some of the components they point out include the memory modules, hard disks, processor, cooling devices, power supplies, and even ports for expansion.
episodes.title: Server Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe performance monitoring methodology and procedures to help you keep your server running optimally. Unfortunately, slow downs happen to servers, so we need to be able to find out why. Tools built into the Microsoft operating systems like, Perfmon, Resmon, and Task Manager help us track down these problems so we can ultimately implement a solution.
episodes.title: Performance Monitoring

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain how to take a system baseline to take a snapshot of normal system operation so that you can determine if and when a server is experiencing performance degradation. They will show you how to create and access the logs and alerts generated by the Perfmon utility, allowing you to compare data at different times under different loads on the server.
episodes.title: Logs and Alerts

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the process a server or PC goes through when booting up. They walk you through each of the startup processes beginning with the Power On Self Test(POST) and BIOS, then moving through the loading of the Windows operating system.
episodes.title: Startup Process

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain some of the common methods for maintaining business continuity like the necessity of taking backups in the case of data loss. They even show you how to setup backups using Microsoft's wbadmin utility built-in to the Windows Server operating system. Other concepts discussed are disaster recovery methods like offsite backups and cold/warm/hot sites. Also implementing Uninterruptible Power Supplies and redundancy methods like Active Directory Restore and Clustering.
episodes.title: Business Continuity

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel walk you through understanding updates; why they're important, where they apply, and implementation practices. Specifically covered are updates for drivers, software, apps, and operating systems as well as an overview of Microsoft's Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) system for update management.
episodes.title: Understanding Updates

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain best practices and procedures used in the troubleshooting method. They cover two different types of approaches to troubleshooting, systematic and specific, and then move into some of the tools found in the Windows Server operating system like performance monitor, resource monitor, event logs, event filtering, and central logging.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Methods
